::: {.question-block}
<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module2_mcq_q47')" data-correct-answer="D">
<strong style="display: block;">
An investor buys a stock at $50 and sells it one year later for $60. During the year, the stock also paid a dividend of $2 per share.  
What is the investor’s total return, and what portion of it represents the capital gain?
</strong>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q47" value="A"> A. Total return = 20%; Capital gain = 2%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q47" value="B"> B. Total return = 22%; Capital gain = 22%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q47" value="C"> C. Total return = 22%; Capital gain = 24%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q47" value="D"> D. Total return = 24%; Capital gain = 20%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q47" value="E"> E. Total return = 20%; Capital gain = 18%</label><br>
</form>
<div id="feedback-module2_mcq_q47" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: D.  
Capital gain = (60 − 50)/50 = 20%.  
Dividend yield = 2/50 = 4%.  
Total return = 20% + 4% = 24%.  
Thus, capital gain contributes 20 percentage points of the total return.
</div>
:::
